prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for ending free rides for their friend. The situation is that the friend has taken rides in their car many times, but only once put gas in (10 dollars) when the author forgot their purse. Now the author is telling the friend to find their own way around.

First, I need to analyze the situation. The friend has been using the author's car for rides, which the author provides by filling up the gas and picking them up. The friend only contributed gas once, which was 10 dollars. The author is now ending the rides. The question is whether the author is in the wrong.

So, the key points here: the author has been bearing all the costs (gas, time, etc.) for the friend's rides. The friend only once contributed a small amount (10 dollars) when the author forgot something. The author is now saying "find your own way around," which is ending the arrangement. 

The user thinks the author is in the wrong, but I need to decide. From a fairness perspective, if the friend has been consistently taking without contributing, and the author is now setting a boundary, is that justified? The author isn't obligated to provide these rides, right? They could have asked for contributions earlier. But maybe the friend didn't, so the author is within their rights to stop. The one time the friend put gas in might not be enough to expect it as a norm. 

But is 10 dollars a fair contribution? If the author usually fills up the tank, which could be more than 10 dollars, maybe the friend's contribution was minimal. Also, the author might not have been compensated for the time, wear and tear on the car, etc. 

So, the author is setting a boundary after the friend's one-time contribution. Is that a valid reason to end the rides? The author could have asked for more gas contributions or set expectations earlier. If they didn't, maybe they can't be surprised if the friend didn't contribute. But the author is now deciding to stop. 

In terms of being an asshole, if the author has been enabling the friend's lack of contribution and is now ending it, maybe that's just being fair. The friend might be used to free rides and now has to adjust. The author isn't in the wrong for setting a boundary after the fact. 

So, the answer would be B (author not in the wrong). The friend was taking advantage, and the author is no longer allowing it. The one-time contribution isn't sufficient to expect the author to continue the rides. The author has the right to stop using their car if they feel it's no longer fair.
